articles.headline: A New Threat From Trump and Old Questions About Its Effectiveness
articles.snippet: Time and again, the president has engaged in a game of geopolitical chicken with Mexico. But there was no more guarantee that the tactic will be any more effective this time than in the past.
articles.abstract: Time and again, the president has engaged in a game of geopolitical chicken with Mexico. But there was no more guarantee that the tactic will be any more effective this time than in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time President Trump vowed all-out retaliation against Mexico for the illegal immigrants crossing the border, he backed off. In April, he gave America’s southern neighbor a year to fix the problem.

articles.headline: There Are 472,000 Words in the Dictionary. For the Spelling Bee, That May Not Be Enough.
articles.snippet: The winners of the 2019 Scripps National Spelling Bee had more in common than an aptitude for spelling: six of the eight used the same coaching program.
articles.abstract: The winners of the 2019 Scripps National Spelling Bee had more in common than an aptitude for spelling: six of the eight used the same coaching program.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seemingly unfazed by the stage lights and television cameras, one gifted adolescent after the next approached the microphone on Thursday night and without a hint of timidity correctly spelled daunting words like “erysipelas” and “aiguillette.”
articles.byline: By Amy Harmon and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Explores Google Antitrust Case
articles.snippet: A case would renew scrutiny of the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of big tech.
articles.abstract: A case would renew scrutiny of the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of big tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is exploring whether to open a case against Google for potential antitrust violations, putting renewed scrutiny on the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of Big Tech, three people with knowledge of the deliberations said Friday.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, Katie Benner and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Virginia Beach Shooting: A City Grieves Its Workers a Day After Horror
articles.snippet: Most of the victims, city officials said, worked for the Virginia Beach government, several of them for decades.
articles.abstract: Most of the victims, city officials said, worked for the Virginia Beach government, several of them for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Eleven of them were civil servants, the kind of people who worked on construction projects and water quality and right of way issues. Another was a local contractor who had come by to talk about a permit.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Glenn Thrush and Sandra E. Garcia

articles.headline: Trump’s Middle East Peace Plan Faces a Crossroads After Coalition Talks in Israel Crumble
articles.snippet: The administration’s plan could end up becoming a vehicle to resurrect the political fortunes of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and protect those of President Trump.
articles.abstract: The administration’s plan could end up becoming a vehicle to resurrect the political fortunes of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and protect those of President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to throw his full weight behind Benjamin Netanyahu’s campaign to save his job as prime minister of Israel. But to do that, analysts and former diplomats said, the president will have to sacrifice any last hopes of proposing a peace plan that is acceptable to both Israelis and Palestinians.

articles.headline: Boeing Built Deadly Assumptions Into 737 Max, Blind to a Late Design Change
articles.snippet: A system that doomed two flights was expected to engage only rarely and originally used two sensors. Critical decisions were based on those factors even when they no longer applied, employees said.
articles.abstract: A system that doomed two flights was expected to engage only rarely and originally used two sensors. Critical decisions were based on those factors even when they no longer applied, employees said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The fatal flaws with Boeing’s 737 Max can be traced to a breakdown late in the plane’s development, when test pilots, engineers and regulators were left in the dark about a fundamental overhaul to an automated system that would ultimately play a role in two crashes.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Natalie Kitroeff, David Gelles and James Glanz

articles.headline: Trump Is Said to Have Overruled Kushner and Other Aides in Threatening Mexico With Tariffs
articles.snippet: President Trump sided with hard-liners in the administration over the objections of top aides, who said punishing Mexico with tariffs would be risky, multiple officials and people briefed on the plan said.
articles.abstract: President Trump sided with hard-liners in the administration over the objections of top aides, who said punishing Mexico with tariffs would be risky, multiple officials and people briefed on the plan said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump pushed ahead with plans to impose tariffs  on Mexico over the objections of several top advisers, including his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, opting to side with hard-line officials who were advocating the move, according to multiple administration officials and people briefed on their plans.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: The Most Powerful Arab Ruler Isn’t M.B.S. It’s M.B.Z.
articles.snippet: Prince Mohammed bin Zayed expanded the U.A.E.’s power by following America’s lead. He now has an increasingly bellicose agenda of his own. And President Trump seems to be following him.
articles.abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Zayed expanded the U.A.E.’s power by following America’s lead. He now has an increasingly bellicose agenda of his own. And President Trump seems to be following him.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, the 29-year-old commander of the almost negligible air force of the United Arab Emirates, had come to Washington shopping for weapons.

articles.headline: Google and Amazon Are at the Center of a Storm Brewing Over Big Tech
articles.snippet: Support for scrutiny of the tech giants is coming from across the political spectrum. For Google and Amazon, any investigations would be a major distraction, or worse.
articles.abstract: Support for scrutiny of the tech giants is coming from across the political spectrum. For Google and Amazon, any investigations would be a major distraction, or worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google and Amazon have thrived as American regulators largely kept their distance. That may be changing.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, David Streitfeld, Katie Rogers and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: California Is Now an ‘Early Primary State.’ Democrats Are Grappling With How to Compete.
articles.snippet: After years of voting late in the presidential nominating process, most California Democrats can start casting ballots by mail in February as Iowans head to their caucuses.
articles.abstract: After years of voting late in the presidential nominating process, most California Democrats can start casting ballots by mail in February as Iowans head to their caucuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Senator Elizabeth Warren bounded onto stage before a crowd of more than 6,000 here — “the biggest one so far,” she announced excitedly — and stayed for nearly two extra hours, past 11 p.m., until everyone who wanted a picture with her had gotten one.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Leah Chase, 96, Creole Chef Who Fed Presidents and Freedom Riders, Dies
articles.snippet: In New Orleans, Dooky Chase’s was the only upscale restaurant that welcomed African-Americans, and it became a gathering place for civil rights leaders.
articles.abstract: In New Orleans, Dooky Chase’s was the only upscale restaurant that welcomed African-Americans, and it became a gathering place for civil rights leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leah Chase, the nation’s pre-eminent Creole chef, always knew what to feed her famous customers.

articles.headline: Inside a Flashy Trump Project in Uruguay: Cash Shortages and Mismanagement
articles.snippet: President Trump’s company had high hopes for a Uruguayan condominium development. But the long-delayed project has become a microcosm of the Trump Organization’s deep problems.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s company had high hopes for a Uruguayan condominium development. But the long-delayed project has become a microcosm of the Trump Organization’s deep problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay — President Trump’s son Eric traveled in January to Punta del Este, a Uruguayan beach town on a spit of land jutting into the South Atlantic Ocean.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Manuela Andreoni

articles.headline: An HBO Question Is Giving AT&T Executives a Headache
articles.snippet: The corporate home of Wonder Woman, Harry Potter and “Friends” weighs how its streaming service can compete on price with Disney, Netflix and Amazon.
articles.abstract: The corporate home of Wonder Woman, Harry Potter and “Friends” weighs how its streaming service can compete on price with Disney, Netflix and Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its acquisition of Time Warner last year, AT&T was on its way toward creating a streaming service that will one day be the exclusive online home for “Game of Thrones” and the blockbuster film franchises centered on Wonder Woman, Batman and Harry Potter.

articles.headline: As Slack Prepares to Go Public, Its C.E.O. Is Holding His Tongue
articles.snippet: Stewart Butterfield, Slack’s chief executive, has been outspoken. Maybe too outspoken for a business software company that is about to go public.
articles.abstract: Stewart Butterfield, Slack’s chief executive, has been outspoken. Maybe too outspoken for a business software company that is about to go public.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Stewart Butterfield, chief executive of the workplace collaboration app Slack, once offended Robert De Niro at an awards event with an irreverent comment, prompting the actor to curse at him from the stage.

articles.headline: A ‘Bridge’ to China, and Her Family’s Business, in the Trump Cabinet
articles.snippet: Elaine Chao has boosted the profile of her family’s shipping company, which benefits from industrial policies in China that are roiling the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: Elaine Chao has boosted the profile of her family’s shipping company, which benefits from industrial policies in China that are roiling the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: The email arrived in Washington before dawn. An official at the American Embassy in Beijing was urgently seeking advice from the State Department about an “ethics question.”
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton, Keith Bradsher and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: The Fox News Primary? How Trump’s Favorite Network Became a Democratic Power Player
articles.snippet: A Sunday town hall with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand was another sign of Fox News’s ability to influence the Democratic primary, despite a ban by party leaders.
articles.abstract: A Sunday town hall with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand was another sign of Fox News’s ability to influence the Democratic primary, despite a ban by party leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three months ago, Democratic Party leaders took a stand: Fox News, President Trump’s favorite channel, and a reliable soapbox for attacks on liberals, was barred from participating in the party’s 2020 presidential debates. The move would ice out the network derided by critics as “state TV” from influencing the outcome of the Democratic primary.

articles.headline: Biden’s First Run for President Was a Calamity. Some Missteps Still Resonate.
articles.snippet: In 1988, Joe Biden was prone to embellishment. Hints of that linger today. But unlike then, his message to voters is clear: He’s a stabilizing statesman in a tumultuous time.
articles.abstract: In 1988, Joe Biden was prone to embellishment. Hints of that linger today. But unlike then, his message to voters is clear: He’s a stabilizing statesman in a tumultuous time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden was riffing again — an R.F.K. anecdote, a word about “civil wrongs,” a meandering joke about the baseball commissioner — and aides knew enough to worry a little.
